name: Akitabare “Koshiki Junzukuri”
pairings: seafood, vegetable, tempura

name: Hoyo “Genji”
pairings: seared tuna, asparagus and artichoke.

name: Hoyo “Sawayaka Junmai”
pairings: sushi, sashim

name: Kamoizumi “Shusen”
character-full: Rich, robust, with a woody shiitake aroma
pairings: duck or foie gras,mushrooms and winter vegetables

name: Kuzuryu “Junmai”
pairings: umami-rich shellfish when heated, beef filet or grilled chicken when chilled

name: Masumi “Okuden Kantsukuri”
pairings: tempura, tofu and marinated chicken or pork dishes.

name: Miyasaka “Yawaraka Junmai”
pairings: good with everything

name: Sohomare “Karakuchi”
pairings: sushi, fish and poultry entrees

name: Sohomare “Tokubetsu Kimoto”
pairings: uni, chutoro tuna, Spanish ham and goat cheese.

name: Tamagawa “Red Label”
pairings: stews, grilled meats, oystrers

name: Tamagawa “Tokubetsu Junmai”
pairings: robust stews and roasts.

name: Tedorigawa “Yamahai Junmai”
pairings: Spicefriendly,  savoury dishes from Middle-Eastern cuisines.

name: Dewazakura “Dewasansan”
pairings: sashimi, oysters, grilled tuna, sea bass and halibut

name: Dewazakura “Izumi Judan”
pairings: Great with salmon roe, caviar, toro and hamachi

name: Dewazakura “Oka”
pairings: lightly dressed salads and white fish sushi or sashimi

name: Dewazakura “Omachi”
pairings: sweet corn croquettes, an omelette, gently seasoned dishes

name: Kokuryu “Junmai Ginjo”
pairings: braised meat, fish and root vegetables

name: Kokuryu “Tokusen”
pairings: umami-rich seafood like squid, scallops and sea bream

name: Koshi no Kanbai “Sai”
pairings: umami-rich seafood such as scallops, mirugai and ika

name: Koshi no Kanbai “Tokusen”
pairings: complements virtually all Japanese foods.

name: Nagurayama “Yokikana”
pairings: scallops, sea bream and abalone as well as seasonable vegetables and salads.

name: Seitoku “Junmai Ginjo”
pairings: ideal choice for sashimi and sushi.

name: Sohomare “Junmai Ginjo”
character-full: Robustly clean with rich, elegant flavour
pairings: white fish sashimi, scallop ceviche and halibut, also with soba

name: Dewazakura “Namagenshu”
pairings: good with edgy flavour combinations of fusion cuisines

name: Kamoizumi “Red Maple”
pairings: Nice with nuts. Best with meat, especially pork and veal chops

name: Akitabare “Daiginjo”
character-full: Light and fragrant, supple and smooth
pairings: well with eggs and white fish. Complements Mediterranean and Italian cuisine

name: Akitabare “Suirakuten”
pairings: versatile dinner sake, making everything it accompanies taste better

name: Dewazakura “Ichiro”
character-full: Billowing meadowy flavours, then a dry, gently
pairings: unadorned dishes that accentuate the flavour of natural ingredients

name: Hoyo “Kura no Hana”
character-full: A truly light sake with sweetness, delicacy and finesse
pairings: salads and light seafood dishes, perfect with lobster, either cooked or sashimi

name: Kamoizumi “Junmai Daiginjo”
pairings: rich seafood dishes like miso-marinated cod, duck and many braised dishes.

name: Kokuryu “Ryu”
character-full: Smooth texture, gentle aroma, incisive taste
pairings: subtlety embracing the flavours of every course.

name: Koshi no Kanbai “Chotokusen”
pairings: nhances the flavour of any food it accompanies.

name: Koshi no Kanbai “Kinmuku”
pairings: enhances the flavour of any food most enjoyable with traditional Japanese cuisine

name: Koshi no Kanbai “Muku”
pairings: well with seafood of all kinds as well as with meat dishes.

name: Kuzuryu “Daiginjo”
character-full: Svelte and smooth, carefully aged, medium-body
pairings: grilled chicken, both yakitori and teriyaki, chinese cuisine. Ideally wagyu

name: Masumi “Nanago”
pairings: complements many non-Japanese foods. Well with French and Italian seafood dishes

name: Masumi “Sanka”
character-full: Fresh and fragrant with notes of peach and anise
pairings: Great with shiromi (white fish) carpaccio, light pasta, chicken and salads.

name: Masumi “Yumedono”
pairings: good with everything or on its own

name: Sohomare “Kimoto Junmai Daiginjo”
pairings: Charcoal-grilled sliced filet, abalone steak, uni, caviar, the richer cuts of tuna

name: Tedorigawa “Iki na Onna”
character-full: Vivacious and saucy, with a caress of wild honey
pairings: crisp Chardonnay. Serve it chilled with flank steak, charcoal-grilled fish or a caesar salad

name: Tedorigawa “Yamahai Daiginjo”
character-full: Supple, racy, with enticing imprint of honey and herbs
pairings: Best with cold dishes that combine meat or fish with vegetables, such as Thai beef salad or Salade Nicoise.

name: Tedorigawa “Kinka”
character-full: Vivid and poised, like plum blossoms at winter’s end
pairings: fresh sashimi, nigiri choices like anago, mirugai and uni.

name: Tedorigawa “Tsuyusanzen”
pairings: A slice of pristine sashimi or a fresh seasonal appetiser

name: Akitabare “Shunsetsu”
pairings: light sidedishes like edamame, tofu and seafood salad

name: Seitoku “Bessen
pairings: Sublime with tempura.
